I’m a bit concerned with the way studies are conducted these days, most are rigged to get the desired results. I’m not saying that maybe this study isn’t accurate, and perhaps I’m the odd one here, but I’m not addicted to my phone and I need it to sleep. I spend most of my days off of my phone and taking care of basic life stuff and all the schoolwork I have to do, but I have insomnia and found that the only way I can get my mind to shut off at night is by watching cooking channels on YouTube. It never fails, and on the nights I try to keep my phone off my mind won’t shut off and I end being up until late the next morning.

Even my dad who grew up there in a house with no ceiling and a donkey carrying buckets of water said he started missing his internet too. So a few days before he left he had wifi installed there. I think this needs more studying, Self reported results by individuals tend to be biased.

1. Link to the study please?
2. How were participants split into groups? Your language almost makes it sound like they chose them. How do we know the non-phone group skewed toward people who already sleep better without a phone?
3. This is soooo generalized, when using a phone in a bedroom can look drastically different between one person 2am doomscrolling and another falling asleep to a guided meditation. I want to see a study that actually accounts for different types of phone usage.
4. People often use phones while in bed BECAUSE they have trouble sleeping. At most this describes a chicken/egg scenario, not a clear causal link.

I know it’s just a short, and I wanna give benefit of the doubt because generally this channel is trustworthy, but this feels so much like bad science “phone bad” clickbait.
